bookmark.privacyNote: Bookmarks persist in local storage. Clear anytime.
breakdown.heading: Transaction History ({{count}})
cex.chainalysisClearAddr: No sanctions identified. Exchanges are unlikely to flag this address.
cex.chainalysisClearTx: No sanctions identified. Exchanges are unlikely to flag this transaction.
cex.disclaimer: These checks cover sanctions screening only. Exchanges may flag addresses for other reasons (mixer usage, high-risk jurisdiction, etc.) that are not detectable with public tools.
cex.disclaimerCoinJoin: This transaction was identified as a CoinJoin. Multiple centralized exchanges are documented to flag, freeze, or close accounts for CoinJoin-associated deposits - even months or years after the transaction. These checks cover sanctions screening only and cannot predict exchange compliance decisions.
cex.ofacClear: Checked against US Treasury SDN list. Client-side - no data sent.
cex.ofacFlaggedPlural: {{count}} sanctioned addresses found. Exchanges will likely freeze funds associated with these addresses.
cex.ofacFlaggedSingular: 1 sanctioned address found. Exchanges will likely freeze funds associated with this address.
cex.privacyNoteTor: Routed through Tor to protect your IP. Chainalysis sees the address but not your identity.
cex.privacyWarningPlural: Sends addresses to chainalysis.com via proxy. The proxy operator also sees the addresses.
cex.privacyWarningSingular: Sends address to chainalysis.com via proxy. The proxy operator also sees the addresses.
cex.sanctionsIdentified: Sanctions identified. Exchanges will likely freeze funds.
cex.torFailed: Tor proxy is unavailable. Proceeding will send the request directly - Chainalysis and the proxy operator will see your IP address.
cluster.coinJoinExcluded: {{count}} CoinJoin transaction excluded from clustering (CIOH does not apply).
cluster.description: Discover linked addresses using common-input-ownership heuristic (CIOH). Follows change outputs one hop. This makes additional API calls and may take a few seconds.
cluster.disclaimer: This is a lower-bound estimate based on one-hop CIOH analysis of the {{count}} most recent transactions. The actual cluster may be larger.
cluster.noLinked: No linked addresses found. This address does not share inputs with other addresses in analyzed transactions.
cluster.severityLarge: Large cluster: {{count}} addresses are linked through common inputs. A chain analysis firm can see all of them as belonging to the same entity.
cluster.severityNotable: Notable cluster: {{count}} addresses linked. Consider using CoinJoin before consolidating UTXOs.
cluster.severitySmall: Small cluster: {{count}} addresses linked through common inputs.
cluster.title: Cluster Analysis
common.connectionClearnet: Not using Tor - mempool.space can see your IP address
common.connectionLocal: Connected to local mempool instance - all queries stay on your network
common.connectionTor: Connected via Tor - your IP is hidden from API providers
common.connectionUnknown: Connection privacy status could not be determined
common.privacyNotice: Queries are sent to mempool.space - your IP is visible. Use Tor or a VPN for stronger privacy.
common.tipMessage: am-i.exposed is free and open source. If it helped you, consider a tip.
common.tipScanQR: Scan with any Lightning wallet, or copy the address below
common.tipToastMessage: This tool is free and open source. Tip to keep it running.
common.v4v: Powered by Value4Value - no ads, no subscriptions, just voluntary support
crosspromo.stuckTx: Transaction stuck or slow? Unstick it in 3 clicks.
errors.address_not_found: Address not found. Check that it's correct and exists on the selected network.
errors.api_custom: Your custom API endpoint returned an error. Check that it is running.
errors.api_unavailable: The API is temporarily unavailable. Please try again later.
errors.api_unavailable_short: API temporarily unavailable. Try again later.
errors.boundary_description: An unexpected error occurred. This is usually temporary - try refreshing the page or starting over.
errors.invalid_input: Invalid Bitcoin address or transaction ID.
errors.network: Network error. Check your internet connection or try again later.
errors.network_custom: Connection to your custom endpoint failed. Open API settings to troubleshoot.
errors.network_short: Network error. Check your internet connection.
errors.not_found: Not found. Check that the address or transaction ID is correct and exists on the selected network.
errors.presend_txid: Pre-send check only works with addresses, not transaction IDs.
errors.rate_limited: Rate limited by mempool.space. Please wait a moment and try again.
errors.rate_limited_short: Rate limited. Please wait a moment and try again.
exchange.activeExchanges: Active exchanges with documented CoinJoin policies
exchange.disclaimer: This information was compiled in {{date}} and may be out of date. Exchange policies change frequently - always verify current policies before transacting. This list is not comprehensive; many exchanges may have undocumented policies.
exchange.rec1: Do not deposit CoinJoin outputs directly to a centralized exchange.
exchange.rec2: Maintain strict separation between privacy wallets and exchange wallets.
exchange.rec3: Never mix coins after withdrawing from a KYC exchange - exchanges monitor where withdrawals go.
exchange.rec4: Use decentralized exchanges (Bisq, RoboSats, Hodl Hodl) for converting CoinJoin outputs.
exchange.rec5: Be aware of retroactive risk - exchanges can re-scan historical transactions at any time.
finding.anon-set-moderate.description: {{count}} outputs have the same value ({{value}}). This gives you some cover - an observer can't easily tell which is yours.
finding.anon-set-moderate.recommendation: For stronger privacy, use CoinJoin to create more outputs with equal values.
finding.anon-set-moderate.title: Anonymity set: {{count}} equal outputs
finding.anon-set-moderate.title_coinjoin: Anonymity set: {{count}} equal outputs (CoinJoin - structural privacy)
finding.anon-set-none.description: All {{outputCount}} outputs have different values. Each one can be easily identified, which is normal for standard transactions.
finding.anon-set-none.recommendation: This is normal for most transactions. CoinJoin creates outputs with equal values, making them harder to trace.
finding.anon-set-none.title: No anonymity set (all outputs unique)
finding.anon-set-none.title_coinjoin: No anonymity set (all outputs unique) (CoinJoin - structural privacy)
finding.anon-set-strong.description: {{count}} outputs share the value {{value}}. An observer can't tell which of these {{count}} equal outputs is yours - this is great for privacy.
finding.anon-set-strong.recommendation: Strong anonymity sets indicate good privacy. CoinJoin transactions maximize this property.
finding.anon-set-strong.title: Largest anonymity set: {{count}} outputs
finding.api-incomplete-prevout.descripti: {{nullCount}} transaction inputs could not be fully resolved. Some heuristics (CIOH, entropy, change detection, script type analysis) may produce incomplete results.
finding.api-incomplete-prevout.recommend: This is common on self-hosted mempool instances. For complete analysis, try using the public mempool.space API.
finding.api-incomplete-prevout.title: Some input data could not be retrieved
finding.coinbase-transaction.description: This is a mining reward transaction that creates new bitcoin. The receiving addresses belong to a mining pool or miner. Mining pools are publicly known, so the origin of these funds is publicly visible.
finding.coinbase-transaction.recommendat: No action needed. Mining payouts are a normal part of Bitcoin. If you want to reduce linkability of mined coins, consider using CoinJoin before spending them.
finding.coinbase-transaction.title: Coinbase transaction (block reward)
finding.dust-attack.description: This transaction sends a tiny amount ({{totalDustValue}} sats) - a common tracking technique. Attackers send small amounts to your address and watch when you spend them, revealing which addresses belong to you. Do NOT spend this with your other funds.
finding.dust-attack.recommendation: Freeze this tiny output in your wallet so it's never spent. If you must get rid of it, send it through CoinJoin or to a throwaway wallet first.
finding.dust-attack.title: Possible dust attack ({{totalDustValue}} sats)
finding.dust-attack.title_coinjoin: Possible dust attack ({{totalDustValue}} sats) (CoinJoin - likely coordinator fee)
finding.dust-outputs.description: This transaction has {{dustCount}} tiny outputs below {{threshold}} sats (total: {{totalDustValue}} sats). These are too small to be worth spending and may be tracking dust.
finding.dust-outputs.recommendation: Be careful spending tiny outputs. Keep them separate from your main funds to avoid linking your addresses together.
finding.dust-outputs.title_coinjoin: {{dustCount}} dust outputs detected (CoinJoin - likely coordinator fee)
finding.h1-round-amount.description: {{count}} of {{total}} outputs are round numbers (like 0.01 BTC). Round amounts make it obvious which output is the payment and which is your change.
finding.h1-round-amount.description_coin: Equal round outputs are expected in CoinJoin transactions - they are the denomination, not a privacy leak.
finding.h1-round-amount.recommendation: Avoid sending round BTC amounts. Many wallets let you send exact sat amounts. Even adding a few random sats helps obscure the payment amount.
finding.h1-round-amount.title: {{count}} round amount output detected
finding.h10-p2pkh.description: This is an older address format that reveals more information than necessary. It also has higher transaction fees.
finding.h10-p2pkh.recommendation: Upgrade to a native SegWit (bc1q) or Taproot (bc1p) wallet for better privacy and lower fees.
finding.h10-p2pkh.title: Legacy address (P2PKH)
finding.h10-p2sh.description: This address format reveals its type when you spend from it, making your transactions easier to identify.
finding.h10-p2sh.recommendation: Upgrade to a native SegWit (bc1q) or Taproot (bc1p) wallet.
finding.h10-p2sh.title: Pay-to-Script-Hash address (P2SH)
finding.h10-p2tr.description: Taproot is the newest and most private address format. All transactions look the same on-chain, whether they use one key or multiple. Adoption is still growing, so fewer people use it than SegWit.
finding.h10-p2tr.recommendation: Taproot is ideal for multisig and complex scripts where it hides the underlying conditions. For single-sig, both P2TR and P2WPKH provide strong privacy.
finding.h10-p2tr.title: Taproot address (P2TR)
finding.h10-p2wpkh.description: This is the most widely used modern address format. Because so many people use it, your transactions blend in with the crowd - great for privacy.
finding.h10-p2wpkh.recommendation: P2WPKH has the largest anonymity set for single-sig transactions. No change needed.
finding.h10-p2wpkh.title: Native SegWit address (P2WPKH)
finding.h10-p2wsh.description: This address format is used for multi-key setups. It reveals the spending conditions when you spend, which reduces privacy compared to Taproot.
finding.h10-p2wsh.recommendation: Consider upgrading to a Taproot-based multisig setup (MuSig2 or FROST) for improved privacy.
finding.h10-p2wsh.title: Native SegWit multisig address (P2WSH)
finding.h11-wallet-fingerprint.descripti: This transaction contains clues about which wallet software was used: {{signals}}. Knowing the wallet helps analysts narrow down who you might be.
This transaction contains clues about which wallet software was used: {{signals}}. These patterns match {{walletGuess}}. Knowing the wallet helps analysts narrow down who you might be.
finding.h11-wallet-fingerprint.recommend: This is hard to avoid. Using Taproot (bc1p) addresses helps because all transactions look the same. Using popular wallets also helps you blend in.
finding.h11-wallet-fingerprint.title_sig: {{signalCount}} wallet fingerprinting signal detected (CoinJoin - less relevant)
{{signalCount}} wallet fingerprinting signals detected (CoinJoin - less relevant)
finding.h13-ofac-match.description: This address matches an entry on the U.S. Treasury OFAC Specially Designated Nationals (SDN) list. Transacting with sanctioned addresses may have serious legal consequences.
finding.h13-ofac-match.recommendation: Do NOT send funds to this address. Consult legal counsel if you have already transacted with this address.
finding.h13-ofac-match.title: OFAC sanctioned address
finding.h13-presend-check.recommendation: This destination looks clean. You can proceed with your transaction.
Ask the recipient for a fresh, unused address. If this is an exchange, consider the privacy implications.
finding.h13-presend-check.title: Destination risk: {{riskLevel}}
finding.h2-change-detected.description: {{signalCount}} patterns suggest which output is your change. When your change is identified, the exact payment amount and recipient are revealed.
finding.h2-change-detected.recommendatio: Avoid sending round amounts. Use the same address type for all outputs. Taproot wallets make this easier.
finding.h2-change-detected.title: Change output likely identifiable ({{confidence}} confidence)
finding.h2-change-detected.title_coinjoi: Change output likely identifiable ({{confidence}} confidence) (CoinJoin - unreliable)
finding.h2-self-send.description: {{matchCount}} of {{totalSpendable}} spendable outputs go back to an address that was also an input. This is a severe privacy failure - it reveals which output is the change and therefore the exact payment amount.
finding.h2-self-send.description_all: Every spendable output goes back to an address that was also an input. This reveals the sender's exact balance and creates a trivial on-chain link.
finding.h2-self-send.recommendation: Use a wallet that generates a new change address for every transaction (HD wallets). Never send change back to the same address.
finding.h2-self-send.title: {{matchCount}} of {{totalSpendable}} outputs sent back to input address
finding.h2-self-send.title_all: All outputs return to input address
finding.h3-cioh.description: This transaction combines funds from {{count}} different addresses. Analysts will assume all {{count}} addresses belong to you. This is one of the most powerful tracking techniques.
finding.h3-cioh.description_coinjoin: Multiple input addresses are linked, but this is expected in a CoinJoin transaction. In CoinJoins, each input typically belongs to a different participant, so CIOH does not apply.
finding.h3-cioh.recommendation: Avoid combining funds from different addresses in one transaction. If you must, use CoinJoin first to break the link.
finding.h3-cioh.title: {{count}} input addresses linked by CIOH
finding.h3-cioh.title_coinjoin: {{count}} input addresses linked by CIOH (CoinJoin - expected)
finding.h3-single-input.description: This transaction only uses one address as input, so there's no way to link multiple addresses together from this transaction alone.
finding.h3-single-input.recommendation: Keep using single-input transactions when possible.
finding.h3-single-input.title: Single input address
finding.h4-coinjoin.description: {{count}} of {{total}} outputs have the same value ({{denomination}}). This is a CoinJoin - a collaborative transaction where multiple people mix their funds together, making it very hard to trace.
finding.h4-coinjoin.description_wabisabi: This transaction has {{vin}} inputs and {{vout}} outputs with {{groups}} groups of equal values - a WabiSabi CoinJoin (Wasabi Wallet). Multiple people mixed their funds together at different amounts, making tracing very difficult.
finding.h4-coinjoin.recommendation: CoinJoin is one of the best privacy tools available. For maximum benefit, do multiple rounds of mixing.
finding.h4-coinjoin.recommendation_wabis: WabiSabi CoinJoins provide excellent privacy through large anonymity sets and multiple denomination tiers. Continue using CoinJoin for maximum privacy.
finding.h4-coinjoin.title: Likely CoinJoin: {{count}} equal outputs of {{denomination}}
finding.h4-coinjoin.title_wabisabi: WabiSabi CoinJoin: {{groups}} denomination tiers, {{totalEqual}} equal outputs across {{vout}} total
finding.h4-exchange-flagging.description: Some exchanges flag or freeze accounts linked to CoinJoin transactions - sometimes months or years later. In documented cases, exchanges have flagged CoinJoins retroactively and even closed accounts for coins that had CoinJoin history from a previous owner.
finding.h4-exchange-flagging.recommendat: Don't send CoinJoin outputs directly to an exchange. Use decentralized exchanges (Bisq, RoboSats, Hodl Hodl) that don't monitor your transaction history. Keep privacy wallets and exchange wallets separate.
finding.h4-exchange-flagging.title: Exchanges may flag this transaction
finding.h4-joinmarket.description: This transaction has {{vin}} inputs from {{count}} addresses and {{count}} equal outputs of {{denomination}} - consistent with a JoinMarket CoinJoin. Multiple people pooled their funds, making it impossible to tell who paid whom.
finding.h4-joinmarket.recommendation: JoinMarket provides good privacy through its decentralized maker/taker model. For stronger privacy, consider multiple rounds of mixing.
finding.h4-joinmarket.title: Likely JoinMarket CoinJoin: {{count}} equal outputs of {{denomination}}
finding.h4-stonewall.description: This transaction matches the Stonewall pattern: 2 equal outputs with 2 change outputs. Stonewall creates genuine ambiguity: an observer cannot tell if this is a single-wallet Stonewall or a two-wallet STONEWALLx2. The 2 equal outputs make the payment amount ambiguous, and each change output could belong to either party.
finding.h4-stonewall.recommendation: Stonewall transactions provide real privacy by creating doubt about the payment amount and fund ownership. For stronger privacy, combine with Whirlpool mixing before spending.
finding.h4-stonewall.title: Possible Stonewall: 2 equal outputs of {{denomination}}
finding.h4-whirlpool.description: This matches a Whirlpool CoinJoin pattern: 5 equal outputs at a standard amount. Whirlpool breaks the connection between your inputs and outputs, giving strong privacy.
finding.h4-whirlpool.recommendation: Whirlpool is one of the strongest CoinJoin implementations. Make sure to also remix (multiple rounds) for maximum privacy.
finding.h4-whirlpool.title: Whirlpool CoinJoin detected ({{denom}} pool)
finding.h5-entropy.description: This transaction has {{entropy}} bits of entropy, meaning there are ~{{interpretations}} possible ways the funds could have flowed. More possibilities = harder to trace.
finding.h5-entropy.recommendation_high: Good entropy level. CoinJoin transactions can achieve even higher entropy.
finding.h5-entropy.recommendation_low: Consider using CoinJoin to make your transactions harder to trace.
finding.h5-entropy.title: Transaction entropy: {{entropy}} bits
finding.h5-low-entropy.description: This transaction has very low entropy ({{entropy}} bits). There's essentially only one way to interpret the fund flow, making it easy to trace.
finding.h5-low-entropy.recommendation: Transactions that are harder to interpret are harder to trace. CoinJoin maximizes ambiguity.
finding.h5-low-entropy.title: Very low transaction entropy
finding.h5-zero-entropy.description: This transaction has one input and one output - there's only one possible interpretation. The fund flow is completely transparent.
finding.h5-zero-entropy.recommendation: Transactions with more inputs and outputs are naturally harder to trace. CoinJoin maximizes this.
finding.h5-zero-entropy.title: Zero transaction entropy
finding.h6-rbf-signaled.description: This transaction signals RBF replaceability. RBF is now standard across virtually all modern wallets and is no longer a meaningful fingerprinting signal.
finding.h6-rbf-signaled.recommendation: RBF is standard practice. Nearly all wallets signal RBF by default, so this reveals very little about the sender.
finding.h6-rbf-signaled.title: RBF (Replace-by-Fee) signaled
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.description: This transaction uses a round fee rate of {{feeRate}} sat/vB. Some wallets use round numbers, which can help identify the wallet software.
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.recommendation: This is a minor signal. Most modern wallets now use precise fee estimation.
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.title: Exact fee rate: {{feeRate}} sat/vB
finding.h6-round-fee-rate.title_coinjoin: Exact fee rate: {{feeRate}} sat/vB (CoinJoin - coordinator fee)
finding.h7-op-return.description: This transaction contains embedded data (OP_RETURN) that is permanently visible on the blockchain.
finding.h7-op-return.description_decoded: This transaction contains embedded data (OP_RETURN) that is permanently visible on the blockchain. Decoded text: "{{decoded}}".
finding.h7-op-return.description_protoco: This transaction contains embedded data (OP_RETURN) that is permanently visible on the blockchain. Protocol: {{protocol}}.
finding.h7-op-return.recommendation: OP_RETURN data is permanent and public. Avoid services that embed unnecessary data in your transactions.
finding.h7-op-return.title: OP_RETURN data embedded in transaction
finding.h8-address-reuse.description: This address has been used in {{txCount}} transactions. Every transaction involving this address can be trivially linked together. Address reuse is the #1 privacy mistake in Bitcoin.
finding.h8-address-reuse.recommendation: Use a wallet that generates a new address for every payment you receive. Never share the same address twice.
finding.h8-address-reuse.title: Address reused across {{txCount}} transactions
finding.h8-batch-receive.description: This address received {{totalFunded}} payments in a single transaction (batch payment). This is not address reuse since it's one transaction.
finding.h8-batch-receive.recommendation: This is typically caused by exchange batched withdrawals. Use a fresh address for the next receive.
finding.h8-batch-receive.title: Multiple UTXOs from a single transaction (batch payment)
finding.h8-no-reuse.description: This address has only received funds once. Single-use addresses are a core Bitcoin privacy practice.
finding.h8-no-reuse.recommendation: Keep using fresh addresses for every receive.
finding.h8-no-reuse.title: No address reuse detected
finding.h8-reuse-uncertain.description: This address has {{txCount}} transactions but the receive count ({{totalFunded}}) appears incomplete. The API backend may not fully index funded outputs. Address reuse cannot be confirmed or ruled out.
finding.h8-reuse-uncertain.recommendatio: Try analyzing this address using the public mempool.space API for more complete data.
finding.h8-reuse-uncertain.title: Address reuse data incomplete
finding.h9-clean.description: No suspicious tiny outputs and a manageable number of unspent funds. This is a healthy state.
finding.h9-clean.title: Clean wallet state
finding.h9-dust-detected.description: Found {{dustCount}} tiny outputs below {{threshold}} sats (total: {{totalDust}} sats). These may be tracking dust - tiny amounts sent by surveillance companies. If you spend them alongside your other funds, it links all your addresses together.
finding.h9-dust-detected.recommendation: Do NOT spend these tiny outputs. Freeze them in your wallet's coin control. If your wallet doesn't support this, consider Sparrow or Bitcoin Core.
finding.h9-many-utxos.description: This address has {{utxoCount}} unspent outputs. Spending many of them together in one transaction links them, reducing privacy and increasing fees.
finding.h9-many-utxos.recommendation: Consider consolidating during low-fee periods, or use CoinJoin to break the link before combining them.
finding.h9-many-utxos.title: Many unspent outputs ({{utxoCount}})
finding.h9-moderate-utxos.description: This address has {{utxoCount}} unspent outputs. Be careful when spending - combining them in one transaction reveals they belong to you.
finding.h9-moderate-utxos.recommendation: Select specific outputs when sending instead of letting your wallet auto-select all of them.
finding.h9-moderate-utxos.title: {{utxoCount}} unspent outputs on this address
finding.partial-history.description_part: This address has {{totalOnChain}} transactions but only the most recent {{txsAnalyzed}} were analyzed. Older transactions may have additional privacy issues.
finding.partial-history.description_unav: This address has {{totalOnChain}} transactions but transaction history could not be fetched. Spending pattern analysis could not be performed, so the score may be incomplete.
finding.partial-history.recommendation_p: For a complete analysis, use a local node or API with higher limits.
finding.partial-history.recommendation_u: Try again later, or use a custom API endpoint with higher rate limits.
finding.script-mixed.description: This transaction uses {{typeCount}} different address formats ({{types}}). Mixing formats makes it easier to identify your change output.
finding.script-mixed.description_coinjoi: Mixed script types are expected in CoinJoin transactions since participants use different wallet software.
finding.script-mixed.recommendation: Use a wallet that keeps the same address format for all outputs. Taproot wallets do this automatically.
finding.script-mixed.title: {{typeCount}} different script types in transaction
finding.script-mixed.title_coinjoin: {{typeCount}} different script types in transaction (CoinJoin - expected)
finding.script-multisig.description: This transaction has {{count}} exposed multi-signature outputs. This reveals all public keys on the blockchain, making it easy to identify the signers.
finding.script-multisig.recommendation: Use Taproot for multi-key setups - it looks identical to single-key transactions on-chain.
finding.script-uniform.description: All inputs and outputs use the same address format. This makes it harder to identify which output is your change.
finding.script-uniform.recommendation: Continue using wallets that maintain consistent address types.
finding.script-uniform.title: Uniform script types
finding.spending-high-volume.description: This address has {{totalTxs}} transactions. High-activity addresses are more likely to be tracked and may be flagged as belonging to a business or service.
finding.spending-high-volume.recommendat: Spread your activity across multiple addresses. Modern wallets do this automatically.
finding.spending-high-volume.title: High transaction volume ({{totalTxs}} transactions)
finding.spending-many-counterparties.des: This address has transacted with {{counterpartyCount}}+ different addresses. The more connections, the easier it is to identify and track.
finding.spending-many-counterparties.rec: Use different addresses for different people. Modern wallets handle this automatically.
finding.spending-never-spent.description: This address has received funds but never spent them - likely cold storage. No spending patterns can be analyzed.
finding.spending-never-spent.recommendat: When you do spend from this address, use coin control and consider CoinJoin.
finding.spending-never-spent.title: Address has never spent (cold storage)
finding.timing-locktime-timestamp.descri: This transaction uses an unusual timestamp setting ({{locktime}}). Most wallets don't do this, which makes the transaction stand out.
finding.timing-locktime-timestamp.recomm: Use a wallet that follows standard practices (Bitcoin Core, Sparrow).
finding.timing-locktime-timestamp.title: nLockTime set to timestamp ({{date}})
finding.timing-stale-locktime.descriptio: This transaction was created about {{diff}} blocks before it was actually sent. This delay can reveal information about how the sender prepares transactions.
finding.timing-stale-locktime.recommenda: Send transactions promptly after creating them.
finding.timing-stale-locktime.title: Transaction held for ~{{diff}} blocks before confirmation
finding.timing-unconfirmed.description: This transaction hasn't been confirmed yet. While waiting in the mempool, anyone watching the network could link your IP address to this transaction.
finding.timing-unconfirmed.recommendatio: Use Tor when sending sensitive transactions. Sparrow and Wasabi support Tor by default.
finding.timing-unconfirmed.title: Transaction is unconfirmed (mempool visible)
history.noBookmarks: No bookmarks yet. Save interesting scans from the results page.
input.descriptionCheck: Check a destination address before you send bitcoin to it
input.descriptionScan: Analyze your address or transaction for privacy leaks
input.errorInvalid: That doesn't look like a Bitcoin address or txid. Check and try again.
input.placeholderScan: Paste a Bitcoin address or transaction ID
install.description: Install as an app for faster access. No app store needed.
install.title: Install am-i.exposed
methodology.calculation_text: Every analysis starts from a base score of 70 - representing a typical Bitcoin transaction with no obviously good or bad characteristics. The base is above 50 because most transactions are not catastrophically bad; they carry the normal, baseline exposure of a transparent public blockchain.
methodology.cross_heuristic_intro: After all heuristics run, the engine applies cross-heuristic rules to avoid false penalties:
methodology.cross_rule_1_text: multiple input addresses in a CoinJoin belong to different participants, so the CIOH penalty is zeroed out
methodology.cross_rule_2_text: equal outputs in a CoinJoin are the denomination, not a privacy leak
methodology.cross_rule_3_text: change identification in CoinJoin transactions is unreliable and penalizing it would be misleading
methodology.cross_rule_4_text: mixed script types are expected when participants use different wallet software
methodology.cross_rule_5_text: wallet identification is less relevant when the CoinJoin already breaks transaction graph linkability
methodology.cross_rule_6_text: small outputs in CoinJoin transactions are typically coordinator fees, not dusting attacks
methodology.cross_rule_7_text: broadcast timing in CoinJoin is coordinated and does not reveal individual participant behavior
methodology.cross_rule_8_text: fee rate and RBF signals in CoinJoin reveal the coordinator, not the participant's wallet
methodology.cross_rule_9_text: CoinJoin structure provides privacy beyond simple output value matching
methodology.grade_aplus_description: Excellent privacy - CoinJoin, Taproot, no reuse, high entropy
methodology.grade_aplus_detail: Uses advanced privacy techniques like CoinJoin that break deterministic transaction links. Minimal metadata exposure and strong anonymity sets make chain analysis unreliable.
methodology.grade_b_description: Good - minor issues, no critical exposure
methodology.grade_b_detail: No major privacy leaks detected. Minor issues like wallet fingerprinting or non-round change amounts may exist but do not enable confident tracing.
methodology.grade_c_description: Fair - notable concerns, moderate tracing risk
methodology.grade_c_detail: Some privacy concerns detected. An analyst could identify patterns like address reuse or change output detection, but the overall picture is still somewhat ambiguous.
methodology.grade_d_description: Poor - significant exposure, confident clustering likely
methodology.grade_d_detail: Significant privacy failures. Chain surveillance can likely cluster addresses and trace fund flows with moderate to high confidence.
methodology.grade_f_description: Critical - severe failures, trivial to trace
methodology.grade_f_detail: Severe privacy failures that make tracing trivial. Issues like heavy address reuse, round amounts, and identifiable wallet patterns create a clear picture for any observer.
methodology.heuristic_h1_description: Flags outputs matching common round BTC or satoshi values. Round amounts typically indicate the payment (not change), letting an observer determine fund flow direction.
methodology.heuristic_h10_description: Assesses the address format: Taproot (P2TR) hides script complexity, ideal for multisig and contracts. P2WPKH (native SegWit) has the largest anonymity set, excellent for single-sig. Legacy (P2PKH) and wrapped (P2SH) leak more information.
methodology.heuristic_h11_description: Identifies wallet software through nLockTime, nSequence, BIP69 ordering, and low-R signature grinding. Approximately 45% of transactions are identifiable by wallet software from structure alone.
methodology.heuristic_h12_description: Flags tiny UTXOs (under 1000 sats) as potential dusting attacks - an active surveillance technique where adversaries send small amounts that, when spent alongside other UTXOs, link addresses via CIOH.
methodology.heuristic_h13_description: Calculates how many outputs share the same value, making them indistinguishable. Higher anonymity sets (as in CoinJoin) mean more possible interpretations of fund flow. Outputs with unique values have an anonymity set of 1 and are trivially traceable.
methodology.heuristic_h14_description: Examines transaction timing patterns including broadcast recency (unconfirmed transactions risk IP correlation), locktime anomalies, and stale nLockTime values that can fingerprint wallet software.
methodology.heuristic_h15_description: Checks whether inputs and outputs use the same script type. Mixed script types (e.g., P2WPKH input with P2TR output) make change detection easier. Uniform script types improve ambiguity. Also flags bare multisig outputs.
methodology.heuristic_h16_description: Address-level analysis of spending behavior including transaction volume, UTXO turnover rate, and counterparty diversity. High-volume addresses or accounts that never spend may indicate specific usage patterns like exchanges or cold storage.
methodology.heuristic_h2_description: Identifies which output returns funds to the sender using address type matching, round amount analysis, and output ordering patterns. Also detects the critical case where outputs are sent back to an input address (self-send), revealing the sender's exact balance. Correct change identification enables multi-hop tracing.
methodology.heuristic_h3_description: If a transaction spends multiple inputs, all inputs are assumed to belong to the same entity. This is the foundational clustering heuristic - the single most powerful tool in chain surveillance. Applied transitively across transactions to build massive address clusters.
methodology.heuristic_h4_description: Detects Whirlpool (5 equal outputs at known denominations) and WabiSabi/Wasabi (large input/output sets with equal-value groups) CoinJoin transactions. CoinJoin is the only heuristic that increases the privacy score.
methodology.heuristic_h5_description: Measures how many valid input-to-output mappings exist. Higher entropy means more ambiguity for adversaries. Uses exact enumeration for small transactions and structural estimation for large ones.
methodology.heuristic_h6_description: Examines fee rate precision and RBF signaling. Round fee rates and specific RBF patterns help identify wallet software, reducing the anonymity set.
methodology.heuristic_h7_description: Identifies embedded data in OP_RETURN outputs - protocol markers (Omni, OpenTimestamps, Counterparty, Runes, Ordinals) and arbitrary text. Permanently visible metadata that distinguishes the transaction. Impact stacks with multiple OP_RETURN outputs.
methodology.heuristic_h8_description: Detects addresses that have received funds in more than one transaction. Address reuse is the single most damaging privacy behavior - it creates deterministic, irrefutable links between all transactions. Carries the harshest penalty, scaling with the number of reuses.
methodology.heuristic_h9_description: Evaluates the UTXO set for count, value distribution, dust detection, and consolidation risk. Large UTXO counts represent future privacy damage if consolidated carelessly.
methodology.heuristics_intro: The engine implements 16 heuristics that evaluate on-chain privacy - 12 at the transaction level and 4 at the address level. Each produces a score impact applied to a base score of 70.
methodology.limitation_1: Entropy calculation is simplified. Full Boltzmann analysis requires expensive enumeration that is impractical client-side for large transactions.
methodology.limitation_2: Only on-chain data is analyzed. Off-chain intelligence (IP correlations, exchange records, human intelligence) that surveillance firms use is not modeled.
methodology.limitation_3: Wallet fingerprinting covers major wallets but cannot identify all software. Novel or obscure wallets may not be detected.
methodology.limitation_4: Some privacy techniques (like PayJoin) are deliberately undetectable on-chain. A good privacy score does not guarantee privacy, and the absence of detected issues does not mean none exist.
methodology.subtitle: How your Bitcoin privacy is scored. Every heuristic documented, every penalty explained. The same techniques chain surveillance firms use - applied client-side to show you the results.
methodology.threat_1_text: group addresses controlled by the same entity using CIOH, change detection, and address reuse
methodology.threat_2_text: connect clusters to real people via KYC anchor points (exchange deposits, merchant payments)
methodology.threat_3_text: follow bitcoin through multiple hops using change detection and temporal analysis
methodology.threat_4_text: identify spending patterns, wallet software, timing, and financial activity
methodology.threat_model_intro: The analysis models the capabilities of chain surveillance firms (Chainalysis, Elliptic, CipherTrace) and KYC-linked exchanges. These adversaries:
methodology.title: Methodology
page.description: Find out what the blockchain knows about you. Paste a Bitcoin address or transaction ID to get a privacy score with actionable findings.
page.tagline: The Bitcoin privacy scanner you were afraid to run.
presend.adviceCritical: Do NOT send to this address. It poses severe privacy or legal risks.
presend.adviceHigh: Ask the recipient for a fresh, unused address before sending.
presend.adviceLow: This destination looks safe to send to.
presend.adviceMedium: Consider asking the recipient for a fresh address.
presend.disclaimerBrowser: Analysis ran entirely in your browser. This is a heuristic-based assessment - always verify independently.
presend.reusedAddressWarning: Sending to a reused address links your transaction to all other transactions involving this address. Chain analysis can trivially trace your payment.
presend.summaryCritical: This address has received funds {{reuseCount}} times. It is almost certainly a service or exchange deposit address - sending here will link your transaction to a known entity.
presend.summaryEscalated: However, heuristic analysis identified concerning patterns.
presend.summaryHigh: This address has received funds {{reuseCount}} times. All senders to this address are trivially linkable. Ask the recipient for a fresh address.
presend.summaryLow: This address appears unused. No significant privacy concerns detected for the recipient.
presend.summaryMediumDataUnavailable: This address shows {{txCount}} transaction(s) but receive data is unavailable. The address is not unused - verify with the recipient before sending.
presend.summaryMediumReceivedOnce: This address has already received funds once. Sending here will create address reuse, linking your transaction to the previous one on-chain.
presend.summaryMediumReused: This address has received funds {{reuseCount}} times ({{txCount}} total transactions). There is reuse, which means your payment will be linkable to previous transactions to this address.
recent.title: Recent scans
remediation.avoidAddressReuseDetail: Use a new address for each payment you receive. Most modern wallets do this automatically.
remediation.avoidOpReturn: Avoid services that embed data in transactions
remediation.avoidOpReturnDetail: Some services leave permanent public data in your transactions (OP_RETURN). Use alternatives that don't leave metadata on the blockchain.
remediation.betterChangeHandling: Use a wallet with better change handling
remediation.betterChangeHandlingDetail: Switch to a wallet that uses the same address format for change and payments. Taproot wallets (Sparrow, Blue Wallet) do this automatically.
remediation.continueCoinJoinDetail: Your CoinJoin gives strong privacy. Keep mixing with Whirlpool or Wasabi. Don't combine mixed and non-mixed funds.
remediation.doNotSpendDust: Do NOT spend this tiny output
remediation.doNotSpendDustDetail: Freeze it in your wallet's coin control. Spending it links your addresses together. If you must get rid of it, send it through CoinJoin first.
remediation.dust-attack.step1: Open your wallet's coin control and freeze this tiny output (mark it as 'do not spend').
remediation.dust-attack.step2: Never spend this with your other funds - it would link all your addresses together.
remediation.dust-attack.step3: If you must get rid of it, send it through CoinJoin or to a throwaway wallet.
remediation.freshStart: Consider starting fresh with better privacy
remediation.freshStartDetail: Use a privacy-focused wallet (Sparrow, Wasabi), create a new wallet, and send your funds through CoinJoin before moving them over. Use Tor for all Bitcoin activity.
remediation.h2-change-detected.step1: Avoid sending round amounts (like 0.01 BTC) - add some randomness so both outputs look similar.
remediation.h2-change-detected.step2: Use a Taproot (bc1p) wallet so all outputs use the same address format, making change harder to spot.
remediation.h2-change-detected.step3: Spend your change separately from other funds to avoid further linking.
remediation.h2-change-detected.step4: Try PayJoin for your next payment - it adds the receiver's funds to the mix, breaking change analysis.
remediation.h2-self-send.step1: Switch to a wallet that uses HD key generation - it automatically creates a new change address for every transaction.
remediation.h2-self-send.step2: Never manually set the change address to your sending address.
remediation.h2-self-send.step3: If your wallet does not support automatic change addresses, consider Sparrow Wallet or Bitcoin Core.
remediation.h2-self-send.step4: For funds already exposed by this pattern, consider using CoinJoin to break the linkability.
remediation.h3-cioh.step1: Use coin control in your wallet to pick which funds to spend - don't let it auto-select.
remediation.h3-cioh.step2: Avoid combining funds from different addresses unless they've been through CoinJoin first.
remediation.h3-cioh.step3: If you need to combine funds, run them through CoinJoin first to break the link between addresses.
remediation.h3-cioh.step4: Use a wallet that lets you label and control individual funds (Sparrow, Bitcoin Core).
remediation.h8-address-reuse.step1: Stop using this address now - never share it again.
remediation.h8-address-reuse.step2: Generate a new address in your wallet. Most wallets do this automatically for each receive.
remediation.h8-address-reuse.step3: Move remaining funds through CoinJoin to break the link to your history.
remediation.h8-address-reuse.step4: If CoinJoin isn't available, send funds to a new wallet through an intermediate address with a delay.
remediation.minimizeMultiInput: Avoid combining funds from different addresses
remediation.minimizeMultiInputDetail: Combining funds from different addresses in one transaction links them together. Pick specific funds when sending. If you must combine, use CoinJoin first.
remediation.stopReusingAddressDetail: Get a new address for every payment you receive. Most wallets do this automatically. Move remaining funds to a new wallet through CoinJoin.
remediation.switchMultisig: Switch to Taproot for multi-key setups
remediation.switchMultisigDetail: Your current setup exposes all public keys on the blockchain. Taproot makes multi-key transactions look identical to single-key ones.
remediation.switchWalletSelfSend: Switch wallets - yours sends change back to the same address
remediation.switchWalletSelfSendDetail: Your wallet sends change back to the same address you spent from, destroying your privacy. Switch to Sparrow, Bitcoin Core, or any HD wallet that generates fresh change addresses.
remediation.upgradeTaprootDetail: Taproot addresses make all transactions look the same on-chain, giving the best privacy. They also have lower fees. Sparrow, Blue Wallet, and Bitcoin Core support Taproot.
remediation.useDecentralizedExchanges: Use decentralized exchanges for mixed funds
remediation.useDecentralizedExchangesDet: Many exchanges (Binance, Coinbase, Gemini, and others) flag or freeze accounts for CoinJoin deposits. Use decentralized alternatives (Bisq, RoboSats, Hodl Hodl) that don't track your history.
remediation.usePayJoin: Use PayJoin or CoinJoin to make transactions harder to trace
remediation.usePayJoinDetail: Simple transactions are easy to analyze. PayJoin adds inputs from the receiver, and CoinJoin mixes funds with other users - both make tracing much harder.
remediation.walletFingerprint: Consider a wallet that's harder to identify
remediation.walletFingerprintDetail: Your wallet software can be identified from transaction patterns. Bitcoin Core, Sparrow, and Wasabi are the hardest to fingerprint.
results.disclaimerBrowser: Analysis ran entirely in your browser.
results.disclaimerHeuristic: Scores are heuristic-based estimates, not definitive privacy assessments.
results.fGradeWarningAddr: This address has severe privacy issues. On-chain surveillance can likely identify the owner and trace fund flows. Immediate remediation steps are recommended below.
results.fGradeWarningTx: This transaction has severe privacy issues. On-chain surveillance can likely identify the owner and trace fund flows. Immediate remediation steps are recommended below.
results.scoringExplainerP1b: (baseline) and are adjusted by each heuristic finding. Negative findings (address reuse, change detection, round amounts) lower the score. Positive findings (CoinJoin, high entropy, anonymity sets) raise it.
results.scoringExplainerP3: The engine runs 16 heuristics based on published chain analysis research. Scores are clamped to 0-100. CoinJoin transactions receive adjusted scoring that accounts for their privacy-enhancing properties.
results.summaryFair: Some privacy concerns detected. Review the findings below.
results.summaryPoor: Significant privacy exposure detected. Remediation recommended.
settings.corsExplanation2: to accept requests from this site. Add this to your mempool nginx config:
settings.optionADesc: Forward your node to localhost to avoid mixed-content blocking:
settings.optionBDesc: Set up HTTPS on your node with Caddy or nginx + Let's Encrypt, add CORS headers, then use your HTTPS URL.
settings.optionCDesc: Visit this site via its .onion mirror in Tor Browser, then enter your mempool's .onion address. Both are HTTP, so no mixed-content blocking.
settings.selfHostHint: Point to your own mempool.space instance for maximum privacy.
settings.title: API endpoint settings
share.textBad: Privacy score: {{grade}} ({{score}}/100) - {{count}} issues found. Address reuse, no coin control, zero privacy hygiene. This is what chain analysis firms love to see.
share.textGood: Privacy score: {{grade}} ({{score}}/100) - solid privacy practices. This is how it should be done. {{count}} heuristics checked.
share.textMedium: Privacy score: {{grade}} ({{score}}/100) - {{count}} issues. Some effort, but chain analysis can still connect the dots. Bitcoin privacy is hard.
shareCard.footerRight: Scan any address or txid at am-i.exposed
sharePrompt.bad: This transaction has serious privacy issues. Share it as a cautionary tale.
sharePrompt.good: Strong privacy practices here. Share it as an example of how it should be done.
sharePrompt.tweetBad: Privacy score: {{grade}} ({{score}}/100). This is what happens when you ignore coin control and reuse addresses. Chain analysis firms feast on transactions like this.
sharePrompt.tweetGood: Privacy score: {{grade}} ({{score}}/100). This is what proper Bitcoin privacy hygiene looks like.

tips.0: Never reuse a Bitcoin address. HD wallets generate a new address for each receive automatically.
tips.1: CoinJoin breaks the common-input-ownership heuristic, making chain analysis significantly harder.
tips.2: Use Tor when broadcasting transactions. Your IP can be correlated with your on-chain activity.
tips.3: Round payment amounts (e.g., 0.01 BTC) reveal which output is the payment and which is change.
tips.4: Taproot (bc1p...) addresses make all transaction types look identical on-chain.
tips.5: Dust outputs (< 1000 sats) may be surveillance dust. Freeze them in your wallet's coin control.
tips.6: Wallet software can be identified through nLockTime, nSequence, and signature patterns.
tips.7: PayJoin has the receiver contribute an input, breaking the assumption that all inputs belong to the sender.
